conclusion: Analyze forces and torques due to the magnetic field to find minimal angular velocity for dipole orientation reversal.
Dipole consists of charges +q and -q separated by distance d in a uniform magnetic field.
Torque experienced by dipole is given by cross product of dipole moment vector and magnetic field.
Dipole moment vector is qd along Z-axis.
Magnetic field perpendicular to XY-plane, expressed as B_z along Z-axis.
Torque about Z-axis is zero due to cross product of vectors in same direction.
Torque components about X and Y axes are -qd B_z d sin(theta) and qd B_z d cos(theta), respectively.
Dipole's angular momentum is product of moment of inertia and angular velocity.
Moment of inertia for rigid rod of length d and mass m is md^2.
Kinetic energy of dipole is half product of moment of inertia and square of angular velocity.
Dipole reversal requires dipole moment change from qd to -qd, implying angle change from 0 to pi.
Work done by magnetic field to rotate dipole equals change in kinetic energy.
Work done by magnetic field is integral of torque over angle from 0 to pi, resulting in 2 qd^2 B_z.
Change in kinetic energy is half product of moment of inertia and difference of final and initial angular velocity squared.
Initial kinetic energy must equal work done by magnetic field for dipole reversal.
Substituting moment of inertia, solve for initial angular velocity squared as 4 q B_z / m.
Minimal angular velocity for dipole reversal is square root of 4 q B_z / m.
